topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: In a world characterized by scarcity

options.answer: we are not limited by time.
individuals need not work to obtain goods.
people must make choices among alternatives.

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Which of the following is the best definition of economics?

options.answer: the study of how a provincial government allocates tax dollars
the study of how consumers spend their income
the study of how producers decide what inputs to hire and what outputs to produce
the study of how individuals, businesses, governments, and entire societies make choices as they cope with scarcity and the incentives that influence and reconcile those choices
the study of how consumers and producers meet each other at the market

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Which of the following is a microeconomic topic?

options.answer: the reasons why a consumer buys less honey
the reasons why the average price level in a country falls
the effect of the government budget deficit on inflation
the reasons why the labour force in a country decreases

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The study of how wages are set for New Brunswick teachers is classified as

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Which of the following newspaper headlines concerns a macroeconomic issue?

options.answer: Why are people buying more SUVs and fewer minivans?
How would a tax on e-commerce affect chapters.indigo.ca?
How would an unexpected freeze in Oxford, Nova Scotia change the price of blueberries in the Maritimes?
Why do grain producers purchase less pesticides?

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The branch of economics that studies the choices of individuals and businesses is

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Each of the following would be considered a macroeconomic topic except

options.answer: the reasons for a decrease in the unemployment rate.
the effect of the government budget deficit on inflation.

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Complete the following sentence. Macroeconomics

options.answer: is primarily concerned with the operation of individual markets in the economy.
deals mainly with the economic behaviour of households.
is the only part of economics to deal with government decisions.
is primarily concerned with the behaviour of the stock market.
is the study of the national economy and the global economy.

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The determination of prices in individual markets is primarily a concern of

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Which one of the following topics does macroeconomics study?

options.answer: effects of government safety regulations on the price of cars
the performance of the global economy
prices of individual goods and services
effects of taxes on the price of gasoline

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Which one of the following topics does microeconomics study?

options.answer: reasons for a fall in the price of orange juice
the effect of a rise in the Canadian dollar on Canada's exports
effect of interest rates on national economic growth
effect of the government budget deficit on employment
determination of total production in a country

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Complete the following sentence. Microeconomics is

options.answer: not concerned with factors of production.
concerned with the size of the total amount of income earned by all households in an economy.
the branch of economics that studies the choices of individuals and businesses.
concerned exclusively with the role of the government in the economy.

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Which of the following would be considered a microeconomic topic?

options.answer: the cause of unemployment in the economy
the effect of the government budget deficit on inflation
the study of how wages are set for mine workers

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The branch of economics that studies the national economy and the global economy is

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The fact that human wants cannot be fully satisfied with available resources is called the problem of

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The problem of scarcity exists

options.answer: only in economies that lack incentives.
only in economies that have incentives.
now but will be eliminated with economic growth.

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: The inescapable economic fact is that

options.answer: there are unlimited wants and limited resources.
there are unlimited resources, and we just have to figure out how to allocate them.
capitalists are always exploiting the workers.
capitalists and unions cannot work together.

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: An incentive ________.

options.answer: could be a reward but could not be a penalty
could be a penalty but could not be a reward
could be either a reward or a penalty
is the opposite of a tradeoff
occurs in the macroeconomy but not in the microeconomy

topic.name: Definition of Economics

question: Scarcity confronts ________.

options.answer: neither the poor nor the rich
the rich but not the poor
the poor but not the rich
families with incomes less than $25,000 a year

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The two big economic questions

options.answer: involve neither self-interest nor social interest.
involve both self-interest and social interest.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The two big economic questions

options.answer: are "what goods and services are produced?" and "how are goods and services produced?"
have nothing to do with goods and services.
do not consider for whom goods and services are produced.
have nothing to do with the way goods and services are produced.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The two big economic questions include all of the following except

options.answer: can choices made in the pursuit of self-interest also promote the social interest.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: When a firm decides to produce more hybrid cars and fewer gas guzzlers, it is answering the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: When a textile firm decides to produce more silk fabric and less cotton fabric, it is answering the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: When a farmer decides to harvest tomatoes using machines instead of migrant workers, the farmer is answering the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Complete the following sentence. Capital is

options.answer: tools, instruments, machines, buildings, and other constructions that businesses use to produce goods and services.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: When a firm decides to produce computers using robots instead of people, it is answering the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: To meet increased demand for its good, a firm decides to hire a few high-skilled workers, rather than hire many low-skilled workers. The firm is answering the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: An art museum decides to offer tours by having visitors listen to CDs rather than have tour guides. The museum is answering the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: To earn income, people sell the services of the factors of production they own. Land earns ________; labour earns ________; capital earns ________ and entrepreneurship earns ________.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The fact that some people can afford to live in beautiful homes while others are homeless is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The fact that a hockey star earns $3 million a year while a teacher earns $50,000 annually is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Complete the following sentence. Entrepreneurship is

options.answer: the human resource that organizes labour, land and capital.
categorized as the factor of production labour.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Sue, who has a law degree, earns $200,000 a year, while Chris, a high-school dropout, earns $5.00 an hour. This is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: A star athlete can afford a garage full of exotic cars while other people can only afford to take a city bus for transportation. This is an example of an economy facing the ________ question.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Complete the following sentence. Financial capital is

options.answer: the tools and machines that are used to produce goods and services.
used in the production of goods and services.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which factor of production earns the most income?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: What choices are best for the entire society?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Self-interest choices are

options.answer: those choices which are best for the person making them.
those choices that are best for all residents of a region.
choices that are agreed to by majority vote.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The expansion of international trade, borrowing and lending, and investment is

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which of the following relates factors of production to the sources of income correctly?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which statement about incomes earned by factors of production is false?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: A tractor is an example of which of the following factors of production?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which one of the following is an example of capital as a factor of production?

options.answer: an automobile factory owned by Ford

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which of the following would an economist classify as capital?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which one of the following is labour?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which one of the following would economists classify as land?

options.answer: an automotive plant in British Columbia
an oil rig in the Atlantic Ocean
an elementary school in Nova Scotia
automobiles parked in a parking lot in Manitoba

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which one of the following is an example of land?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which one of the following is an example of a factor of production?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which one of the following is an example of capital?

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The creation of a successful movie illustrates choices made in self-interest that also achieve the social interest if ________.

options.answer: the movie has a higher attendance than any other movie produced that year
the movie is produced at the lowest possible cost, and the movie gives the greatest possible benefit
the movie addresses a social issue
the movie is an Academy award winner because an Academy award winning movie is most popular with the movie-going public
the movie is produced in a country where workers typically earn less than workers in North America

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: The creation of a successful movie can influence the main questions that economics seeks to answer. Choose the statement that is false.

options.answer: The movie influences the how question because the movie can create new production techniques, which can be used in subsequent films.
The movie influences the for whom question because the people who earn higher incomes through the movie production buy more goods and services.
The movie influences the when question because movie crews work on many different films and must be available for the entire production.
The movie influences the what question because it can lead to spinoff goods or a new movie genre, which can result in the production of similar films.
The movie influences the how question because it can use unknown actors or Academy Award winners.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Choose the correct statement.

options.answer: Canada produces more services than goods.
Canada produces more goods than services.
Canada produces an equal quantity of goods and services.
China's production of services is a greater percentage of its total production than Canada's.
Canada's production of manufacturing is a greater percentage of its total production than China's.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: In Canada ________ percent of the adult population have completed high school and ________ percent have a university degree.

topic.name: Two Big Economic Questions

question: Which of the following is not a factor of production?

options.answer: the water used to cool a nuclear power plant
the effort of farmers raising cattle
the management skill of a small business owner
the land used by a farmer to grow wheat

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Opportunity cost is

options.answer: the value of your favourite activity.
the money you spend on food, shelter, and clothing.
the marginal benefit from an activity.
the highest-valued alternative that we give up to get something.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: During the next hour John can choose one of the following three activities: playing basketball, watching television, or reading a book. The opportunity cost of reading a book

options.answer: depends on how much the book cost when it was purchased.
is the value of playing basketball if John prefers that to watching television.
is the value of playing basketball and the value of watching television.
depends on how much John enjoys the book.
is the value of watching television if John prefers playing basketball to watching television.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Sally has to decide whether to study for her economics test or her accounting test. If she chooses to study for accounting, her opportunity cost of studying accounting is

options.answer: less than the value of studying economics.
not comparable to the value of studying economics.
equal to the value of studying economics.
the future lost wages that will occur if she fails her accounting exam.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: When the government of Alberta chooses to build more roads, the required resources are no longer available to provide better health care facilities.  This situation illustrates the concept of

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: The concept of opportunity cost

options.answer: is relevant only for European countries.
suggests that individuals can achieve all they want.
suggests a major increase in public education spending means a reduced expansion in the public healthcare system.
is relevant only for developed countries.
is relevant only for developing countries.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Which one of the following is a necessary consequence of scarcity?

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: To make choices, people must

options.answer: be able to carry out complex mathematical calculations.
have unlimited access to information at no cost.
evaluate the values of alternative actions.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: When the government chooses to use resources to build a dam, those resources are no longer available to build a highway. This illustrates the concept of

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: What is the definition of marginal benefit?

options.answer: the cost of an increase in an activity
the sum of benefit and cost that arises from an increase in an activity
the cost of a decrease in an activity
the benefit that arises from an increase in an activity
the benefit that arises from a decrease in an activity

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: When asked in an interview what she missed the most because of the time she spent training for the Olympics, a rower, who lived on her own, answered "a normal social life." She also revealed that she had given up a job that paid $30,000 per year to train fulltime. She received a grant of $8,000 per year from Sport Canada, but this failed to cover all her training expenses. Her food and rent were $5,000 per year and training expenses were $12,000 per year. Aside from the value of a normal social life, what is the annual opportunity cost, expressed in dollars, to this rower of "Going for Gold"?

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Saskatchewan had more hospitals than Ontario, despite having one-tenth the population. The Saskatchewan government closed many of these hospitals in spite of widespread local protests. Which one of the following arguments is true?

options.answer: Since hospitals have positive benefits, they should never be closed.
If Saskatchewan had more hospitals than Ontario, it must have had too many hospitals.
The Saskatchewan government must have thought the marginal benefit from one of these hospitals exceeded its marginal cost.
The Saskatchewan government must have thought the marginal benefit from one of these hospitals was less then its marginal cost.
The communities where these hospitals existed bore no costs from these decisions, because they did not pay for any of the hospital operating costs.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: "There can be too much of a good thing." This statement suggests that

options.answer: choices made in self-interest cannot be applied to many economic decisions.
a good may be produced to the point where its marginal cost exceeds its marginal benefit.
certain goods and services such as education and health care are inherently desirable and should be produced regardless of costs and benefits.
a good may be produced to the point where its marginal benefit exceeds its marginal cost.
a good may be produced to the point where its marginal benefit is equal to its marginal cost.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Which of the following sayings best describes opportunity cost?

options.answer: "Love of money is the root of all evil."
"Boldly go where no one has gone before."
"There's no such thing as a free lunch."
"Baseball has been very good to me."

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: If you take an additional class this term, you can graduate earlier. This is an example of

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Marginal benefit is the

options.answer: additional benefit from a decrease in an activity.
additional benefit from an increase in an activity.
opportunity cost of a decrease in an activity.
opportunity cost of an increase in an activity.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Complete the following sentence. Marginal cost is

options.answer: the total cost of an activity.
the cost of a decrease in an activity.
the cost of an increase in an activity.
the opportunity cost of a decrease in an activity.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: The big tradeoff is the tradeoff between

options.answer: current consumption and a higher future standard of living.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Monika will choose to eat a seventh pizza slice if

options.answer: the marginal benefit from the seventh slice is greater than its marginal cost.
the marginal benefit from the seventh slice is less than its marginal cost.
the total benefit from all seven slices is greater than their total cost.
the total benefit from all seven slices is less than their total cost.
she has enough money to pay for it.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question:
Before starring as Tony Stark in Iron Man, Robert Downey Jr. had played in 45 movies that had average first-weekend box office revenues of a bit less than $5 million.  Iron Man grossed $102 million in its first weekend. The success of Iron Man ________ the opportunity cost of hiring Robert Downey Jr.
Movie producers now have ________ incentive to hire Robert Downey Jr.

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: The night before a history test, you decide to go to the movies instead of reviewing your notes. You get 60 percent on your test compared with the 75 percent that you normally score. You ________ a tradeoff ________, and the opportunity cost of your evening at the movies was ________.

options.answer: faced; between a higher test score and an evening at the movies; the 15 percent fall in your grade
did not face; because your roommates agreed you should go to the movies and not study; zero
did not face; because you made the best choice; zero
faced; between a higher test score and an evening at the movies; the mark of 60 percent on your test
did not face; most students get 60 percent on history tests; the mark of 60 percent on your test

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: A university decides to change its late night bus service between the campus and student housing from a fare-based service to a free service.  This statement means that the incentive to ride the bus ________ and the opportunity cost of a bus ride ________. The university's decision is a ________ decision.

options.answer: remains the same; remains the same; macroeconomic
remains the same; remains the same; microeconomic

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Refer to Fact 1.1.1. The cost of regenerating East London ________ an opportunity cost of hosting the 2012 Olympic Games ________.

options.answer: is not; because few people attending the 2012 Olympics will spend much time outside Olympic venues
is; if the costs of the East London regeneration is equal to a significant percentage of the total amount spent by London taxpayers to host the 2012 Olympics
is; if the regeneration of East London would not occur unless London hosted the 2012 Olympics
is not; because regenerating East London is an unnecessary expense
is; if the property taxes of people living in East London increase

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: You have the choice of going on vacation to Florida for one week, staying at work for the week, or spending the week doing fix-up projects around your house. If you decide to go to Florida, the opportunity cost of the trip is ________.

options.answer: working or doing fix-up projects, depending on which you would have done otherwise
working, because you would be giving up dollars
nothing because you will enjoy the trip to Florida
variable depending on the weather you leave behind in Canada

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Laura is a manager for HP. When Laura must decide whether to produce a few additional printers, she is choosing at the margin when she compares ________.

options.answer: the total revenue from sales of printers to the total cost of producing all the printers
the extra revenue from selling a few additional printers to the extra costs of producing the printers
the extra revenue from selling a few additional printers to the average cost of producing the additional printers
the revenue from selling HP's printers as compared to printers from competing companies, such as Lexmark
the cost of producing HP's printers as compared to printers from competing companies, such as Lexmark

topic.name: The Economic Way of Thinking

question: Which of the following creates an incentive to increase the amount of an activity?

options.answer: an increase in the marginal cost of the activity and a decrease in the marginal benefit from the activity
a decrease in the marginal cost of the activity and an increase in the marginal benefit from the activity
constant marginal cost and constant marginal benefit from the activity
an increase in the marginal cost of the activity and an equal increase in the marginal benefit from the activity
a decrease in the marginal cost of the activity and an equal decrease in the marginal benefit from the activity

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Statements about "what ought to be" are called

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Statements about "what is" are called

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Which of the following statements is normative?

options.answer: Scientists should not make normative statements.
Warts are caused by handling toads.
As e-book prices fall, people buy more of them.
If income increases, sales of luxury goods fall.
There is more caffeine in a cup of tea than in a cup of coffee.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: A positive statement is

options.answer: capable of evaluation as true or false by observation and measurement.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: A positive statement is

options.answer: what is currently believed about the way the world operates.
an opinion that cannot be verified.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: A normative statement is

options.answer: capable of evaluation, as true or false, by observation and measurement.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: "The rich should face higher income tax rates than the poor." This is an example of

options.answer: neither a normative nor a positive statement.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Which of the following is an example of a positive statement?

options.answer: Canada should cut back on its use of carbon-based fuels such as coal and oil.
Increasing the minimum wage results in more unemployment.
Every Canadian should have equal access to health care.
The Bank of Canada ought to cut the interest rate.
Canada should have lower tax rates for wealthier Canadians.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Complete the following sentence. Economic models

options.answer: do not answer questions about the economic world.
include most of the details of the economic world.
describe some aspect of the economic world, but include only those features needed for the purpose at hand.
answer questions that arise from normative statements.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: The scientific purpose of simplifying assumptions in an economic model is to

options.answer: eliminate the need for further testing of the implications of the model.
abstract from the complexities of the real world those issues that are not important for the issues under examination.
eliminate the possibility of personal bias in the model.
add necessary hypotheses to the problem.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Model A is superior to model B if

options.answer: it contains more real world detail than model B.
it contains fewer unrealistic assumptions than model B.
its predictions correspond more closely to the facts than the predictions of model B.
it is preferred by a majority of researchers in a public opinion poll.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: In choosing among alternative models, economists generally have the strongest preference for models that

options.answer: have assumptions that are close to exact replicas of reality.
are detailed and complex, with every available fact and figure included.
have few assumptions and are as simple as possible, even if they cannot predict very well.
predict better than any other that is available.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: A normative statement is a statement regarding

options.answer: the assumptions of an economic model.
the predictions of an economic model.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: "The rich face higher income tax rates than the poor" is an example of a

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: An economic model is tested by

options.answer: examining the realism of its assumptions.
comparing its predictions with the facts.
comparing its complexity to other models that deal with similar issues.
the Testing Committee of the Canadian Economic Association.
comparing its descriptions and examining the realism of its assumptions.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Which of the following is a positive statement?

options.answer: Low rents restrict the supply of housing.
Low rents are better for a city than high rents.
Owners of apartment buildings ought to be free to charge whatever rent they want.
Government should control the rents that apartment owners charge.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: "The rich face higher income tax rates than the poor, which is not good since it is the rich who provide jobs for the poor." This is an example of

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: An economic model is

options.answer: tested by examining the realism of its assumptions.
useful if it predicts well, even if its assumptions are not realistic.
tested by the Testing Committee of the Canadian Economic Association.
not useful unless it predicts with 100 percent accuracy.
not useful because it simplifies real problems.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Select the best statement about economic models.

options.answer: An economic model must always be correct in its predictions or it must be discarded.
An economic model is evaluated based on the realism of its assumptions.
An economic model should not generate predictions about actual events in the real world, since it discusses only abstract events.
An economic model will be discarded if its predictions are often in conflict with the facts.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: To disentangle cause and effect, economists use economic models and use ________ to test the predictions of those models.

options.answer: the what, how, and for whom questions
personal economic policy, business economic policy, and government economic policy
natural experiments, statistical investigations, and economic experiments

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question:
Which of the following statements are positive?
1.  The federal government should increase production of biofuels.
2.  Air travel has increased since September 11.
3.  The greatest number of accidents are caused by drunk drivers.
4.  We ought to have a cure for cancer.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question:
Which of the following statements are true regarding "positive" statements?
I.	They describe what "ought to be."
II.	They describe what is believed about how the world appears.
III.	They can be tested as to their truthfulness.

options.answer: None of the statements are true.

topic.name: Economics as Social Science and Policy Tool

question: Which of the following is a normative statement?

options.answer: Next year's inflation rate will be under 4 percent.
Consumers will buy more gasoline over the December holiday period than they bought during the summer holiday period even if the price of gas is 10 cents a litre higher than it was during the summer.
Government cuts in welfare spending impose an unfair hardship on the poor.
A wheat shortage or surplus is always the result of federal government policies.
Hurricane Irene caused more damage in the United States than Hurricane Katrina.

question:
Consider the following information on cola sales by number of cases for a typical university residence floor:

Temp.	Price (dollars per case)	
(°C)		10.00	12.50	15.00	17.50
  15		50	40	30	20
  20		60	50	40	30
  25		70	60	50	40
  30		80	70	60	50
  35		90	80	70	60
	Cola sales and cola prices are

options.answer: negatively related at low temperatures, but positively related at high temperatures.

topic.name: Appendix: Graphing Relationships Among More Than Two Variables

  25		70	60	50	40

  35		90	80	70	60

options.answer: negatively related at low prices, but positively related at high prices.
